Certainly not an outspoken cherry flavor. Its there, nothing more. Complex, but is waiting to be discovered, like a young girl unaware of het beauty. A cheesy character, especially in the aftertaste. Still lacks a bit of depth, but that wil come with ageing.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2005 Copenhagen beer marathon 2004. Red color,
Sour cherry aroma and taste, medium body, sour finish.
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2005 Bottle @ Plan B, Cph. Nose of cherries, sourness, tartness, marcipan. Lovely deep red body with a medium pinkish head. Sour and cheesy flavor, tart cherries.  Good stuff.

Bottled at GBBF 2004, courtesy of Duff - thanks. Im not going to eulogise over it as much as Duff does., nor remain as unmoved as SilkTork.  Its a good Kriek from one of the premier Lambic producers but, as usual, I prefer the straight geuze to the fruit versions. Theres certainly an authentic manure aroma, with noticeable cherry fruit. The flavour has a lot of woody dryness. Quite easy drinking for a trad lambic. Overall, pretty good, but I wasnt blown away.

Bottle. This is the real deal. My favourite fruit lambic to date.  I still have the taste in my mouth, even after 3 weeks since trying it. This is sour as usual, but more balanced than most. Subtle juicy, cherry sweetness, i can taste some fleshy cherry in here, but its not sweet, very dry. Of course theirs the standard earthy cheesy barnyardy aromas, flavours, but this just seemed to have something else, but im really not sure what it was. This beer is so juicy, puckering, but not overly so, like so many lambic beers can be.  Really amazing. Perfect mouthfeel, just the right dose of refreshing sourness.

Sampled at the RBESP 2004
Lactic nose.
Dark red, low pink head.
Nice beries, a hint barn.
Good dryness, refreshing.

Bottled. 
Hazy, pale pink colour. Cherry stone and marzipan nose. Woody, sourish flavour with an acidic sourness. Baccy dry finish!

Bottle. Thanks Duff. Aroma is mildly interesting - there is vanilla, paint, plastic & wood, but I'm not getting anything outstandingly special. With some lambics, and especially some funky dry ciders, the aroma keeps dragging me back because of shifting notes of interest, or a compelling whiff of barnyard. But I'm not getting that here. The aroma is surprisingly flat and dull. The appearance is of murky rhubarb. I think there is a very fine line between a murky red being stunningly attractive or stunningly revolting; but this achieved the distinction of simply being dull. Mouthfeel is very dry. Flavours are woody, raspberry, tannic, cherry - but very dry, thin, unripe cherry - not a luscious, juicy morello cherry. The whole thing quite pleasantly musty, but very painful to drink. I struggled with this. I found the mouthfeel too dry, slightly acidic, and not at all rewarding or inviting. The difference between an ordinary beer and a great beer can sometimes be in the subtle detail. Here it centres on the nature of an individual's reaction to the special cherries used. I'm not keen on the slightly unripe flavour of these cherries - prefering something with a little more sweetness.  This is not a bad beer at all - just something not to my taste.

Dark red w. small pink head.
A lot of cherry, cherry pits, almond, wood, non-agressive acidity, pleasent mouthfeel.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2004 Bottled.  Massive thanks to Duff for smuggling this through the doormen at GBBF and sharing it with (in order of rating of the beer) Joeh, myself, Chris_o and SilkTork.  I think a couple of the Danish lads had a swig too.  A fantastic sour woody welcoming aroma to this pinky red beer with a baby pink coloured head.  The taste is sour but not over sour.  There is a hint of fudge in there too, and once the cherry taste has filled the mouth there is then a smooth mouthfeell of Angel Delight type smoothness.  A wonderfully brewed beer fully deserving of the praise it receives here.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2004 Bottle Conditioned at the Great British Beer Festival, Kensington Olympia, London. (Thursday Session). Thanks to Duff for bringing this one. Cloudy burgundy. Extremely COMPLEX, woody, sourness, a taste of the cork. Brilliant beer.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2007 Color is a reddish pink.  It is opaque.  Aroma is yeasy with an abundances of cherry.  Slight spice in the flavor.  Mouth feel is like champaign, very bubbly.  Finish is most tart, but accompanied with a fair amount of sweetness.  My favorite of the new beers I enjoyed with MartinT, tiggmtl and  Rastacouere.

Bottled: Reddish coloured. Light cloudy. Huge white head with a red gleam. Sweets, fruit (cherry), earthnotes and a great sourness in the aroma. Very balanced flavour. Earth, cherry, sharp acidic sourness, light background sweetness. Its all there for you to enjoy. Is cleansing, dry and smooth in the end. A really top class beer. Alas I got to this beer. Ive brought it home from Belgium after buying it at Delirium Cafe for 25. It was worth every penny and I would buy it again if possible.

Great cherry aroma, pure cherries and acidic tang. Cloudy strawberry hazy with thin pink head. Medium-light body with soft carbonation. Tart puckering cherry aroma, lactic gueuze notes. Finish is chalky bitter, cherry sour. Great lambic. Smooth cherry after.
UPDATED: JAN 10, 2005 Cask @ Akkurat, StockholmSo smooth, so sweet, so tart, so frity, so complex. In one word: So good. Almost worth the price.
Beautiful deep dark red coloured. Great aroma of cherries, almonds and oak. Very fruity flavour with a great complexity and sourness. A wonderful and exclusive kriek.
Cloudy dark redbrown color, short pink head. Aroma is soft, krieken, some marzipan and oak. Taste is tart, fruity, bit more sharp, slight alcohol.

dutch ratebeer lambic-meeting. Aroma is fruity (cherries and woody. Hazy, dark red coloured with an intense pink head. Taste is fruity (cherries) and hints of cherrienuts, tartness, oak and marzipan. Alcohol is noticable. Dry palate.
Aroma is cherry,  tart and a little oak. Hazy, dark red color, small pink head, fair lace. Light sweet, sour, some oak, cherry and cherrynuts. Quite full, little dry, very soft.
Dutch ratebeer lambic-meeting: Dark red coloured, pink head. Tart lambic aroma, some oak. Fruity kriek flavour, quite sour. Alcohol is more present than in many other krieks.
deep hazy red, pink head.  funky solvent, cherries, cinnamon and mineral aroma.  nutty,  woody and cherry flavous go nicely with the sour lemon and funky cheese.  a very stylish lambic.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2004 This is maybe the most beautiful beer of the more than 700 I have seen so far!!! Pours a tall frothy deep pink head on a hazy deep red body - WOW! Aroma is extremely delicious, sweetnsour fruity and flowery with tones of almonds and plenty of sweet cherries. Very full and heavy, you can really smell the high quality. Flavor is acidid and well balanced. Wood and cherry notes and also some almond here! Very complex and not too sour. Nice dry woody finish.

This is definately one of the best beers I have ever had and again I must say a huge thanks to Jacob Lövenlund for bringing this amazing beer home from Belgium!! Amazing stuff!!

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2006 (2003 bottle): Clean, full raspberry aroma playing with very funky apple scraps...A quirky yeast heart beating away an orderly acidity...A smidge of cinnamon on top and minerals in the back in a fuller mouthfeel than their regular Kriek...A very promising youth which still needs to wisen up a bit to reach the decadent sagacity of their Framboos...Many thanks to my friend Joris!!...

Dark red with a pink head - very pretty.  Aroma of leather and cherries. Respectable amount of funk, but not assertively so.  Ditto the acidity, which is ably balanced with sweet cherry notes and a dryish, nutty character.

This one brings the funk. Cinammon, cherry, horse-blanket aroma. Murky brownish-red with pink head that diminishes completely. Cinammon, huge sour cherries, tart, puckering flavour. Decent carbonation. Engaging mouthfeel. Bottle (enjoyed with MartinT, mr_kimchee, Oakes and Rastacouere).

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2010  Bottle brought back by MartinT to whom it was given by incredibly generous JorisPPattyn. Cheers to both. Enjoyed also with Oakes, Kimchee and tiggmtl  Appearance is a beautiful bloody red with a thin diminishing pink head. The red is so brilliant that it scores a 5 anyway. Aroma is complex of lambic funk. Spicier than most with cinnamon, cloves. The cherries are very nice, feeling unriped, both black and red cherries, intense and bold for a lambic. Earthy mold. Palate is very lactic with its typical yoghourt sourness, balsamic and citric, moderately salty. Funky brett with nutty, earthy branches and leafy undertones. It didnt strike me as spectacular from the first sip and sniff, but it grew on me and I realised I drank my glass very fast. I like its grapey vinous character and as weird as it sounds, to me, this is a quaffable offering despite its a real crime to just think about drinking this fast! This is a very complex kriek, with a good backing medium body and medium-high carbonation. Just what a brewery!  Lowering from 4.6 to 4.3. Outstanding lambic, but not an absolute favourite.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2007 2007-11-01, vintage 2004, 3 years old, courtesy of Jacob (Hildigöltur), 8-5-8-4-16=41Cloudy red color with a persistent thin head. Delicate aroma, perfect balance between the kriek, kriek kernels and the cellar touch. Quite smooth mouthfeel, high carbonation, a lot of citrusy sourness, light cherries, astringent, very woody. Great balance2004-01-28, 9-5-6-3-14=37Cloudy dark red color; pink-reddish head. Wonderful cherry aroma, cherry kernels, and light vinegar. Sour, quite dry, smoother than other lambics; some cork. Too short finish. Thanks Jens (Ungstrup) and Jacob (Lövenlund) for sharing this bottle.

Bottled at SBF 2003.
Dark pinot noir red colour. Hazy.
Spicy aroma with acidic  spicy cherry tones.
Acicid flavor with spices, cinnamon and olives. Acicid finish.
This is a top ten beer.   
The balance between the  spicy wild grown Scharbeek cherries and the acidic lambic of Armand Denbelder is prefect. This is as close  to a fine pinot noir you get by using cherries and beer. You would think that the difference between the regularly used Slovenian sour cherries and the original Scharbeek ones shouldn´t be that big, but it´s huge. Armand for this  got hold of 900 kg of cherries. This one is rare. If you see it, buy it.

Ultra-superb indescribable deep red colour; good dense pink head. There is also an ultra-flunky deposit at the end. Concentrated cherry aroma, full as nothing else but the bursting of a fresh, ripe sour cherry in one's teeth. Superb-tart taste, concentrated full-cherry flavour, neither sweet, neither outspoken acidity. There is a lambic underbuild, but is definitely subjugated to the all-conquering fruit flavours. All the above doesn't prevent it from a quite vicious acid-burn. Full fruity mouthfeel. Armand wanted this to be a flash from the past - and that's what it is. Now that real Schaarbeekse (in fact, virtually wild) krieken are getting rare and not commercially available anymore, he proved that if one really wants, one can make true tradition alive once more.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2004 [Bottled at Stockholm Beer Festival] A beutiful red beer with a fast disappearing pink head. The aroma is sweet with strong cherry notes. The flavor is sour with light cherry notes - a nice flavor but not fantastic. A good kriek - but I've had them better.

Bottle. GBBF2003 (kriek tasting session). Deep red colour, slight haze, initially good cherry red head and moderate condition. Big thick aromas of cherry and almond mingled with lambic notes. Quite dry in the mouth but full bodied and cherry heavy in the mouth with a slight apple tart lambic edge. Long dry and nutty almond finish.
Excellent.

GBBF 2003 - tutored tasting with Lorenzo Dabove: First smell is like an pine tree forest, kind of rhasberry syrup, of course cherry, some marcipan tones and citrus. Soft carbontation in this wonderful deep dark purple pink liquid. Smooth not sharp but dense bitterness, scratches the back of the throat - great - Iwantalambic :-)

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2003 Bottled. The bottle is unlabelled, according to Akkurat this is because it is still noy officially sold. It pours dark clear red with almost no carbonation, probably because it is still really young. Acidic aroma of fresh black cherries. Very vinous, even more so thanks to the low carbonation. Firm and clean. The finish is full of citric acid and a light touch of fruity bitterness.
